Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Functional, genetic, and taxonomic diversity of plant-fungal interactions along climatic gradients and their role in climate change driven species migrations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climates are currently warming at unprecedented rates. Species must move to track the changing climate or evolve to tolerate warmer conditions; those that fail to do so face extinction. Most plant species, especially forest trees, rely on intimate associations with microbial species living in soil in order to capture the resources they need for proper growth. Little is known about how these invisible, but very important, soil microbes are distributed across the continent, and how they will respond to climate change. In this project, the genetic, taxonomic, and functional biodiversity of soil microbial communities from forests across the eastern US will be characterized to test for parallel latitudinal patterns with respect to climate. Trees and soil microbes will likely not move at equal speeds as climates change. Therefore, experiments will test the functional consequences for tree growth for situations where microbial species migrate slower or faster than trees. This research will allow for more precise predictions about how forests will change as a function of the changing biodiversity of the fungal symbiont community during climate warming.

This research will have several broader impacts for society at large. The project will incorporate citizen scientists from across the eastern US in collecting samples for the soil survey, in order to connect the public with original research. Undergraduate students (including women and underrepresented minorities) will be mentored in hands-on research experiences during the project and encouraged to develop independent research projects. By helping to improve our ability to predict ecological changes in response to climate change, this research will increase our ability to mitigate and adapt to the undesirable consequences of a rapidly warming world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview In order to survive across the broad range of environmental conditions they face, forest trees associate with a diverse group of microorganisms that live in or near their roots. These microbial communities include beneficial species that help the trees access water or nutrients, pathogenic species that slow the growth or kill trees and seedlings, and decomposers who recycle organic material to make nutrients available to plants. In this project, we explored how these plant-microbial interactions varied across large spatial scales, and how they could contribute to a tree species’ ability to withstand changing climates or shift its distribution to track historical climates. We found that trees that associate with a particular group of fungal symbionts, ectomycorrhizal fungi, were better able to withstand warming climates at their southern range edge. Within a specific tree species, we found that individual trees associated with a lower diversity of ectomycorrhizal fungi when they grow at the edge of their current geographic range. We also found that within individual tree species, populations were both adapted and maladapted to their local microbial communities, such that small scale movements of plant populations could be beneficial, but large scale movements that severely disrupted the historical plant-microbial interactions could be detrimental. Finally, we found that the nature of the tree-microbial interaction depended on the abiotic soil conditions; tree seedlings grew best when grown with the microbial community that best matched the conditions of the soil in which the seedling grew. Biologist predict that in order to survive in changing climates, tree species will need to either gain increased tolerance to warmer or drier conditions on their equatorial range boundary, or disperse to new locations to track their historical climate. Our results suggest that interactions with microbial communities in soil, especially rhizosphere fungi, may play a crucial role in both of these processes.

 

Intellectual Merit: The results of this project contribute to a growing understanding of the importance of rhizosphere microbiomes for performance of individual plants, evolution of plant populations, and organization of plant communities. Specifically, this work has documented novel biogeographic patterns in tree-fungal interactions that may have important consequences for how forests respond to changing climates. This new knowledge may allow researchers and land managers to better predict the response of specific tree species and whole communities, and potentially inform management decisions such as assisted migration of tree populations and/or microbial communities.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has had broader impacts via training of the next generation of scientists, outreach to lay citizens, and generation of new understanding that could potentially improve forest management practices in the future. This project supported the training of two early career scientists and six undergraduate students. Our citizen science project has involved hundreds of participants, many of them children, in authentic scientific research and lead to an increased appreciation of fungi in forest health for a number of participants. The understanding gained through our research about tree and fungal geographic distributions may be used to inform forest management strategies in the face of changing climates.
